column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.3
#T_SP=webanno.custom.StanzaNER|value
#Text=Sicán/Lambayeque cultural site systematically looted from the early 20th century to the present .

#Text=The archaeological site of Batán Grande , now within the Santuario Histórico Bosque de Pómac , is located in the small coastal valley of La Leche in the Pitipo District of the Lambayeque Province on Peru ‘ s North Coast , about 41 km from the city of Chiclayo .
#Text=The site was created by the Lambayeque Culture , a subset of the Sicán Culture .
#Text=What archaeologists have termed Batán Grande occupies an area of around fifty five square kilometres .
#Text=Because of the massive area the site covers , it is often discussed in terms of its constituent adobe pyramids , known colloquially as huacas , seventeen of which make up the site .
#Text=These include Huaca Loro , Huaca Tres Ventanas , and Huaca la Merced .
#Text=Batán Grande appears to have been a major centre during the Middle Sicán period , a cultural florescence that was aided by the decline of the nearby Wari and Middle Cajamarca cultures .
#Text=Research indicates that Batán Grande was largely abandoned between 1050 and 1100 AD , the result of thirty years of severe drought and subsequent societal breakdown .

#Text=‘ A Mecca of Grave Looting ’ Izumi Shimada , the foremost authority on the archaeology of Batán Grande who began excavating at the site in 1978 , refers to it as ‘ a Mecca of grave looting ' , noting that ‘ [ t ] hese destructive clandestine operations have not only prevented serious fieldwork but also effectively obscured the complexity and significance of archaeological remains ’ .

#Text=During his early work at Batán Grande , Shimada recorded over 20,000 ‘ deep pits and numerous bulldozer/land grader tracks from the looting ’ which he believes occurred from the 1930s until the 1960s .
#Text=This , in itself , is an imprecise estimate of the extent of the Batán Grande looting based on aerial photography .

#Text=Shimada recorded that a single looters ’ pit could result in the looting of over half a dozen burials in a technique that employed a series of horizontal tunnels which radiated out from the single central shaft .
#Text=Shimada has since recorded over 100,000 looters ’ pits .
#Text=Peruvian archaeologist Walter Alva estimated that ninety per cent of Peruvian gold artefacts in international museum collections originated from the looting at Batán Grande .

#Text=The majority of gold objects in the private Museo Oro del Peru in Lima , which consists of the collection of Peruvian businessman Miguel Mujica Gallo , are alleged to be the result of the Batán Grande looting .
#Text=Many of these objects have become cultural icons in Peru : they are some of the most familiar images of the country ’ s ancient past .

#Text=Shimada notes that because the looted Batán Grande objects that appear on the art market are primarily fine elite goods , a ‘ one-sided picture ’ of the site has emerged , the unfortunate consequence being that many of the gold artefacts were subsumed under the designation ‘ Chimú Culture ’ .
#Text=Such a lumped grouping prevented the accurate study of local artistic , technological , and social development within the greater Middle Sicán period .
#Text=The Aurich Family Early looting at Batán Grande was tied to the enormous power of Peru ’ s pre-1968 landed aristocracy .

#Text=The site was largely owned by the Aurich family who , from before the 1930s until around 1970 , employed ‘ an organized looting army ’ of campesiños , rural peasants , who already bound to them via the hacienda system .
#Text=Eventually this looting enterprise included heavy machinery resulting in what Alva has called ‘ the most extensive pillage in the New World ’ .
#Text=The looting of the huacas at Batán Grande appears to have started in earnest in the early 1900s when the hacienda was owned by Juan José Aurich Pastor .
#Text=Aurich ’ s sons , Edmundo and Oswaldo Aurich Bonilla , inherited the hacienda in 1970 , but the property was taken from them during Peru ’ s 1973 agrarian reform .
#Text=During this period the campeseños that the Auriches once employed gained collective land title to the site , which they continued to loot .

#Text=After losing their claim to the site , the Aurich brothers were reportedly in financial straits , at least comparatively , and are alleged to have engaged in antiquities dealing and appraisal until at least the late 1990s .
#Text=The Aurich brothers are linked to another major illicit antiquities case , the looting and recovery of a gold backflap from the site of Sípan .
#Text=Atwood records that the Aurich brothers were friends of Denis Garcia , the Miami-based intermediary who attempted to sell the backflap to the FBI .
#Text=Garcia and his wife lived in Chiclayo in the 1960s , during the height of both the Batán Grande looting and the Aurich brothers ’ fortunes .
#Text=Garcia ’ s wife recalls being shown some of the gold archaeological objects that the Auriches had amassed .

#Text=Furthermore , Atwood alleges that the Auriches were acquainted with Manual Bacigalupo Remy , the man who is said to have purchased the looted Sipán backflap in 1992 once it was removed from the village of Sipán .
#Text=Citing a Bacigalupo family friend as a source , Atwood states that Edmundo Aurich advised Bacigalupo during his purchase of the backflap .
#Text=The looting at Batán Grande did not go unnoticed , even during its earliest phases .
#Text=Julio Tello , the ‘ father of Peruvian archaeology ’ , inspected the looting at Batán Grande in the 1937 as a representative of the Museo de Arqueología Peruana .
#Text=Reportedly the Auriches did not allow him onto their property , but Tello was able to conduct preliminary excavations in the area of Huaca La Merced and Huaca Tres Ventanas .
#Text=This work was detailed in a series of newspaper articles for the Lima-based newspaper El Comercio .

#Text=Again , due to the power of the hacienda owners at that time , there was little that Tello or other archaeologists could do either to stop the looting or to mandate archaeological intervention on Aurich property .
#Text=Other Threats to the Site Looting is not the only threat to the integrity of Batán Grande .
#Text=The area is extremely prone to flooding , especially in El Niño years .
#Text=In 1983 , a flash flood destroyed 80 per cent of one of the huacas and flooding in 1997 undermined the foundations of the Huaca del Oro .
#Text=The El Niño events of 1983 actually caused the La Leche River to change its course to be within seventeen feet of that pyramid .
